This is an implementation-based view of the tests: i.e. they
will e=
ither be run or not run.

The distinction I was trying to make - and I thin=
k David as
well - is based on the cause and nature of the dependency.
For t=
he sake of argument, I'll try to redefine what you're
calling Hard and Soft=
 along those lines.

Hard: Test A does something (sets state) upon which B =
depends. 
For example, A may write to a data store and B might try to 
read=
 the information back. Or A might create a complex object
and B might try t=
o call a method on that object. If we allow 
this sort of thing, then there=
 is no choice but to run A first
and it makes sense to not run B at all if =
A fails. However,
I would not want a unit test framework to allow it.

Soft=
: Test A tests some functionality upon which some other
functionality, test=
ed by B, depends. Therefore, if test A 
fails, Test B will either fail as w=
ell or be inconclusive, 
so nothing further can be learned from test B. In =
this case,
a testing framework could respond in a number of ways to
the dep=
endency:
1) Run the tests in order, skipping B if A fails.
2) Run the tests=
 in an arbitrary order, but skip B if A 
already ran and failed.
3) Run the=
 tests in an arbitrary order, not skipping any
of them but organize reporti=
ng in such a way that a failure
of A takes precedence over a failure of B.
=

As a framework author, I can see that allowing the user to
specify orderin=
g is a simpler implementation. But I think
it's more interesting to imagine=
 the user specifying the
nature of the dependencies and allowing the framew=
ork to
figure out a strategy.

Charlie
